description: The national commissioner of the Icelandic police raises the alert level of the response to COVID-19 to emergency phase on March 6th, following the confirmation of the first transmissions of the virus within Iceland.
Iceland issues travel ban on non-EU/EEA/EFTA or UK national starting from March 20th

description: In Iceland from June 15th, tourists will be able to provide a health certificate or opt for a coronavirus screening at Keflavik airport, instead of completing a two-week quarantine.
In Iceland from June 15th, tourists will be able to provide a health certificate or opt for a coronavirus screening at Keflavik airport, instead of completing a two-week quarantine.

In Iceland, from July 13th, for Icelandic residents and citizens returning home have to on arrival complete a period of “heimkomusmitgát” (home-coming contagion caution). This means will they be tested for COVID-19 at the border and they will also be required to undergo a second free PCR test at a local healthcare centre four to five days later. Until they get the results of the second test Icelanders should:

Maintain two-metre distancing
Only attend gatherings of up to ten people
Avoid high-risk individuals e.g. the elderly
Avoid physical contact

Heimkomusmitgát is not the same as quarantine; Icelanders will be  permitted to use public transport, go to shops and meet family and friends whilst they await test results.
Iceland launched a tracing app on April 1 to track potential Covid-19 infections.
Icelandic health authorities have in cooperation with the medical research company deCode Genetics undertaken for the COVID-19 virus among the Icelandic population since the 13th of March.

description: Icelands Chief Epidemiologist and deCODE Genetics start collecting blood samples from the general public in order to help determine how widespread COVID-19 infection has been within the Icelandic population on May 4. Donating blood for the survey is voluntarily. People undergoing blood tests for other reasons will also be asked to donate a sample. The blood samples will also be tested for antibodies. Those, who give blood will be notified of their test results.
The government of Iceland announced on September 16th 2020 to conduct random testing within the University of Iceland as well as the greater Reykjavík area due to a spike in cases.

Iceland launches website on March 13 that informs about Covid-19 containing what one need or want to know about the virus, including how to protect oneself, how Iceland is responding, and special information for tourists

description: Change in who the policy applies towards - quarantine used to only apply to certaun high risk areas, whereas it now applies to all areas outside of Iceland.
Iceland is enforcing a 14-day quarantine is for all residents of Iceland entering the countrystarting March 19th.
Iceland announced fines between £360-3590 for violations of the 14-day mandatory quarantine, starting from the 29th of March
The chief epidemiologist of Iceland implemented isolation for all persons who are ill with COVID-19 or suspected to have the virus from the 13th of March.

Iceland sets ut guidelines for restaurants and tour operators from March 14. Restaurants were asked to re-arrange their seating to at least two meters between seats, asking that only families and other groups in regular close contact would be seated together, that menus would be washed between each use, and that hand sanitation be available at entry and encourage guests to use them. Tour operators have been asked to offer hand sanitiser at every entry point and encourage passengers to use them, to use back doors if available, make sure that passengers embark and disembark with enough space in between each, and skip using every other row to ensure proper space between passengers.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Iceland ordered the closure of swimming pools, gyms, bars, clubs, slot machines and museums starting on March 23. description: Iceland announce that from August 5 the number of people allowed at swimming pools and bathing places is reverted back to the ruling from earlier this summer. That means that the number of guests may never exceed half of the maximum number of guests allowed under the operating license. Children born in 2015 and later are not included in this number. This is valid until August 13.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Iceland announced that From august 5 Supermarkets over a thousand square meters in size may allow a maximum of 200 customers in total. Smaller supermarkets may accommodate up to 100 people at a time, provided that the conditions for distance limits are met. The changes are valid until August 13th.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Supermarkets/grocery stores") is allowed to open with conditions

description: Icelands parliament will only address Covid-19 related matters from March 20 to April 20. All meetings related to matters that do not concern COVID-19 will be postponed until later in the year.

Iceland prolongs the ban on gatherings over 20 people and the closure of schools from April 13 to May 4.

description: The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March. The maximum number of people allowed to gather indoors has increased from 200 to 500 people from June 15th to July 5.

The Icelandic government announced a ban on gatherings of more than 100 entering into force on the 16th of March.  From July 31 gatherings of over 100 people will be banned, this applies to all public spaces, including shops. Children born after 2005 are exempt from this rule. The ban is expected to last until August 13.

Iceland cancels a number of events and festivities over Merchant’s weekend that takes place August 4 to August 6. This as a response to the new COVID-19 restrictions in Iceland, such as Einnar með allur in Akureyri, Sæludaga in Vatnaskógur and Innipúkinn in Reykjavík. Pride, the Skjaldborg Festival in Patreksfjörður and Þjóðhátíð, the annual outdoor festival held in Vestmannaeyjar, have likewise been canceled.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

The City of Reykjavík offers short-term emergency houses to those who lost their housing due to Covid-19 crisis. This service will be in operation for four months. The emergency housing will be available to people regardless of their legal domicile. They will be allowed to stay in the short-term housing until their case has been channelled to the municipality in which they live.
Iceland allows visitors in nursing homes again starting at may 4th. Only one person will be allowed to visit at a time.
